message: It’s a new year and the first day of the 115th Congress. Conservatives have a mandate, and in 2017 we have the opportunity to put our country back on track.

Today, I voted for the Midnight Rules Relief Act to stop last-minute regulations from crushing the economy.  This is not a partisan issue. Administrations of both parties have issued midnight rules in the past during the last year of a president’s term—particularly between Election Day and Inauguration Day. America needs a solution that guards against improper issuance by either party.

Today I spoke on the House floor about how the media could play a much more constructive role. They could report the good news for once, instead of trying to drive a wedge between people. Good news like that Americans are more confident about the future than they have been in 20 years.

Today I supported one of our oldest and and strongest allies, Israel, by rejecting a United Nations resolution that condemns some Israeli settlements and calls for immediate halt to further development. The Obama administration had the opportunity to veto the dangerous and counterproductive resolution in December but did not. My statement here:
I'm thankful for law enforcement men and women who protect and serve our communities across the country. #LawEnforcementAppreciationDay
Good news for Texas startups! Today in the House we passed the HALOS Act which helps startups to more easily access potential investors.

This evening I voted in support of the Regulatory Accountability Act. This bill, which I wrote the original of as Chairman of the Judiciary Committee in 2011, provides relief to hardworking Americans by putting strong checks and balances on regulations from the executive branch. We need to cut the red tape that hampers economic growth.    http://gph.is/2iGFItL

This week I had the pleasure to visit with Michael Sheeds, a Marine Corps veteran from Bandera, Texas. In 2016, Mr. Sheeds reached a milestone most of us could never imagine; as a driver for Warner Enterprises, he's achieved over 3 MILLION safe driving miles!
Today we celebrate Dr. King and his commitment to democracy, justice and unifying Americans; his legacy is everlasting. #MLKDay
NA
Governor Perry is an excellent choice to lead our nation’s Energy Department.
NA
At the inauguration, President Donald Trump directly spoke directly to Americans. It was an inspiring experience and I was so glad to be there. We're off to a great start. #inauguration2017

Thanks to all who visited my office last week for our inauguration open house! We had a great time seeing so many Texan faces and hearing your stories, and we appreciate the pictures you've shared from your trip. I hope all enjoyed our nation's capital and have made it back home safely.
Check out these beautiful photos taken in Kendall County #TX21
This afternoon the House voted to permanently ban taxpayer funding for abortion. #prolife

This week, Congress is addressing the lack of immigration enforcement and the spread of dangerous sanctuary policies that have failed the American people and harmed too many lives.  We owe it to the families of those who lost loved ones to take action to prevent these horrible crimes. They have waited far too long.

The 44th March for Life is today in Washington, DC - here's what you should know about the world’s largest annual pro-life demonstration: http://www.cnn.com/2017/01/26/politics/march-for-life-need-to-know/  Starting at 10:45 CT, you can livestream the rally and March at www.sba-list.org/mfl-live

Today, countless Americans gathered in Washington, D.C. for the March for Life and to testify to the sanctity of life and the dignity of each human person. Since 1973, Americans have descended upon our nation’s capital to remember the millions of children that never had a chance to live. Above all, the March for Life is a positive proclamation that all lives are worth living, all lives are worth cherishing, and all lives are worth protecting.
Anyone who wants to protect Americans from terrorist attacks should support President Trump’s immigration executive orders. Here are the facts:

BREAKING: After conducting a thorough, serious process, President Trump announced this evening his nomination of Judge Neil Gorsuch to the Supreme Court of the United States.  Here's my statement on the nomination: “President Trump has long spoken of his conservative vision for our country’s next Supreme Court Justice being in the mold of the late Antonin Scalia. Last November, the American people decided what type of Justice they wanted for the vacancy on the Court. President Trump made it clear that he would nominate a jurist who would interpret and defend the Constitution as intended by our Founders. He has done just that by nominating Judge Neil Gorsuch.”
NA

Today at a House Judiciary Committee hearing, we addressed one of our key agenda items for the 115th Congress with my bill, the Lawsuit Abuse Reduction Act (LARA).   While we must protect the ability of Americans to seek redress through the courts when they are truly damaged or injured, there are measures we can take to reduce the wasteful burden that truly frivolous lawsuits impose on American competitiveness. Like excessive regulation, frivolous lawsuits are a drain on businesses, entrepreneurs, innovators, and hardworking Americans. We can and must do better.  LARA passed in the committee today by a vote of 17-6.  I look forward to working with my colleagues to get this commonsense bill to President Trump’s desk.
The American people are smarter than the media thinks http://www.cnsnews.com/blog/craig-bannister/rep-lamar-smith-american-people-are-smarter-media-thinks

Yesterday, I had the honor of presenting US Army Sgt. (Ret.) Guadalupe Alvarado of Austin a Purple Heart medal and six more medals and awards he earned for his service in Vietnam.   Sgt. Alvarado enlisted in the US Army in 1965. He was wounded by an explosion outside of Phan Thiet on August 26, 1968. Mr. Alvarado was awarded the Purple Heart medal while in the hospital in Vietnam in 1968 but it was lost when he was transitioning hospitals to the United States.   I am grateful for the opportunity to help Mr. Alvarado in replacing this medal and thank him and all veterans for their service and sacrifice for our country.
This week, Pack 9 Webelos II of Bryker Woods Elementary hosted me as their special guest. These young leaders had great questions and I wish them the best of luck in the move up to Boy Scouts!

This week, representatives from community colleges across the 21st district met with me in Washington to give an update on their educational initiatives. The Austin Community College District delegation told of the unique courses and research offerings they provide metro Austin and Central Texas. The Alamo Colleges District trustees and staff shared about their growing workforce development programs, including those at the Greater Kerrville & Central Texas Technology Centers. Very exciting news in higher education!

Today in the House we passed H.J. Res. 43 which allows states to prioritize women’s health over abortion. The bill overturned an Obama Administration rule that forced states to use Title X health care funds to fund abortion services through organizations like Planned Parenthood. #prolife

Are you a family member, counselor or educator of a young person   might have an interest in pursuing a college education while preparing to be an officer of the U.S. uniformed services? To attend the United States Military Academy, the United States Naval Academy, the United States Coast Guard Academy and the United States Air Force Academy, students must first obtain a nomination.   On Sunday, March 5 from 2-4, my office will be hosting an event open to all those in South and Central Texas interested in the Service Academies at UTSA with Service Academy and ROTC representatives to share information about the Academies and nomination process. Learn more at http://lamarsmith.house.gov/media-center/press-releases/service-academy-day-for-hs-students-at-utsa-march-5. Please share!

Happy Presidents’ Day!   Today we celebrate the incredible presidential leadership our country has seen since our nation’s birth and the presidency of George Washington. President Washington notably said in his first annual message to the new country, “Knowledge is, in every country, the surest basis of public happiness.” The Founders’ intellectual curiosity was pivotal in the creation of this great American experiment we still take part in today. Thank you to Washington and presidents since who sacrificed much to serve our nation.

This afternoon I led a roundtable discussion with Fredericksburg community leaders about tax reforms to come under Republicans'  Better Way plan. They had helpful feedback on our plan to make our broken tax code simpler and fairer.

Today I had the opportunity to speak with juniors and seniors at Our Lady of the Hills Catholic High School in Kerrville. They came with great questions on education policy and the three branches of government at both the state and federal level. We also had a question on the Service Academies (reminder - Service Academy Day is March 5!).

Did you know James Avery Craftsman jewelry is made right here in Central Texas? Their top notch staff gave me a tour of their new manufacturing facilities in Kerrville. Hundreds of Texans are employed here and at the other surrounding facilities, and more jobs are on the way. #MadeinTexas.

We had great conversations today in San Marcos with San Marcos Mayor John Thomaides and the City Council, San Marcos Chamber of Commerce, McCoy's Building Supply and Greater San Marcos Partnership about federal and local partnerships and issues affecting area economic development.

Service Academy Day is one week away! If you're a Texas student, parent/relative, teacher or counselor interested in learning more about the military academy nomination process, I encourage you to attend this valuable event at UTSA next Sunday, March 5 from 2-4 p.m. You can find more info at https://lamarsmith.house.gov/services/military-academy-nominations  Last spring I met with 2016 nominees before they reported to their respective military academies. They now represent Texas at the US Air Force Academy, United States Military Academy, United States Merchant Marine Academy and United States Naval Academy. I look forward to meeting the next group!
I was honored to attend the signing of two important STEM bills at the White House yesterday.

While the Battle of the Alamo was being fought in San Antonio de Bexar, 170 miles away in Washington-on-the-Brazos, delegates met to formally announce Texas' intention to separate from Mexico and to draft the constitution of the new Republic of Texas. It was March 2, when the original and five copies of the declaration of independence were made and signed by 59 men.

Just two days until Service Academy Day at UTSA! We welcome all students, family members, educators and faculty interested in learning more about our nation's five U.S. Service Academies and what the nomination process entails.   http://www.expressnews.com/militarycity/article/Lamar-Smith-10969576.php

Congratulations to Our Lady of the Hills Regional Catholic High School - Boys Basketball TAPPS 3A State Champions! I had the honor of visiting with some of these talented young men a couple weeks ago at their campus in Kerrville.

The health care insurance market is in a death spiral and is in need of a quick response. Without action to fix the mess Obamacare created, premiums and deductibles would continue to go up while the quality of patient care stagnates or declines.  The two pieces of legislation we have introduced uphold our pledge to repeal and replace the Affordable Care Act. Our plan would eliminate Obamacare’s unpopular taxes and mandates, expand choice, improve access, and lower costs. We would ensure coverage for those with pre-existing conditions and young Americans can stay on their parents’ plan until they are 26. Our goal continues to be affordable care for all Americans. This plan take us in the right direction.
The NASA Transition Authorization Act of 2017 provides bipartisan, bicameral guidance for NASA as we usher in new era of space exploration. The bill now moves to the President's desk.

Today in the House we passed a bill which provides critical funding for our national security. The 21st Congressional District is home to Joint Base San Antonio-Ft. Sam Houston and over 60,000 active duty servicemembers, veterans and their families.   This legislation provides funding for a strong, robust active and reserve force. It will also ensure that the training and equipment they need to carry out their missions are available. It also gives troops a raise and includes full medical benefits for soldiers, military families and retirees.  I will continue to work for the servicemen and women who sacrifice so that all Americans can be free.

This morning the House passed a bill I introduced to protect innocent Americans from lawsuit abuse.   Everyday attorneys file frivolous lawsuits that cost Americans their livelihoods. These attorneys engage in legalized extortion and try to force individuals to settle out of court instead of paying huge court costs. There is currently no disincentive to deter attorneys from filing frivolous claims. The Lawsuit Abuse Reduction Act (LARA) requires attorneys who file junk lawsuits to pay the court costs of those they sue to discourage baseless claims.

Last night I hosted a tele-town meeting with thousands of constituents from across the district. Over the next several weeks, I will be doing more of these meetings in an effort to reach all of you.   In these tele-town meetings, I take questions directly. We do not screen callers. With the American Health Care Act being introduced earlier this week, we had many questions from constituents asking how the legislation would affect them. I also had questions on the due process clause in the Constitution, care for our Veterans, and national security.   In addition to taking questions, we also do several survey questions through the tele-town meetings:  * When asked if they approve or disapprove of Obamacare, 33% of participants said approve and 60% said disapprove.  * When we asked what the most important issue facing our country is, the top response given was border security at 26%.  * Lastly, we asked participants if they think the government should balance its budget. An overwhelming 77 % said yes. Nine percent said no, and 14% were undecided.
Happy birthday to the American Legion. For 98 years the organization has served the needs of veterans of the U.S. Armed Forces and their families.

San Marcos leaders San Marcos Mayor John Thomaides, acting City Manager Steve Parker, and City Council members and I had a great discussion on priorities for the city including the airport, transit and economic development - very important issues as the population in the I-35 corridor continues to expand.

ICYMI: I spoke with WOAI-TV about the Lawsuit Abuse Reduction Act (LARA), my bill which passed in the House and is now awaiting a vote in the Senate. LARA helps to prevent frivolous lawsuits that destroy innocent Americans' reputations and livelihoods.

Today in the House we passed the VA Accountability First Act of 2017. This legislation allows the VA Secretary more flexibility to remove, demote or suspend employees who are engaged in bad behavior and not performing the duties our veterans need. A recent study completed by the U.S. Government Accountability Office found that, on average, it takes six months to a year, to remove a permanent civil servant in the Federal Government, though it often takes longer.  It’s unfair to the vast majority of honest and hardworking employees at Texas VA facilities when the agency doesn’t hold bad actors accountable. The bill has widespread support from Veterans Service Organizations. It's my hope that the Senate will quickly consider this bill that aims to create a culture of accountability at the VA.
Happy St. Patrick's Day!
With President Trump's signature on the NASA Transition Authorization Act we put America back on a path to being a global leader in space.

Today is National #AgDay! Texas farmers and ranchers play a vital role in our society, as my bluebonnet seed packet reminds us. They have a while longer to go before blooming in D.C. like they're doing down in Texas now (see picture from last year).   On Ag Day in D.C., we did have the chance to meet with Texan Carlie Hollingsworth, a Texas FFA state officer and student at Texas A&M. She spoke on how through agricultural education, FFA makes a positive difference in the lives of students by developing their potential for premier leadership, personal growth and career success.
Congratulations to Alamo Area Council of Governments (AACOG) and Joint Base San Antonio! #MilitaryCityUSA

Recently at a visit to Starbucks in San Antonio, their staff shared with me their plan to hire 25,000 veterans and military spouses by 2025. This includes Kelsey, an Army spouse and Starbucks new hire. This is great news for Texas’ 21st district which is home to over 60,000 veterans, current members of the military and their families.
ICYMI - last night the Spurs honored Richard Overton of Austin, the oldest living WWII Veteran. Overton served in the Pacific Theater as part of the 1887th Engineer Aviation Battalion.
Today in House Judiciary Committee, we'll discuss restoring the enforcement of our nation's immigration laws - watch here:

Today marks the first-ever National Vietnam War Veterans Day, 44 years since the last remaining troops withdrew from Vietnam. Last night, President Trump signed the Vietnam War Veterans Recognition Act into law. The bill designates March 29 as National Vietnam War Veterans Day, and it encourages Americans to display the U.S. flag.  Many veterans didn't receive the recognition they deserved upon returning home because the war was unpopular. Today, and each March 29th going forward, we pause to specifically honor this generation of veterans for their selflessness and sacrifice. We must never forget the hardships endured by those who fought in the Vietnam War.

I met with Texas Farm Bureau members including constituents from Bandera, Blanco, Comal, Hays, Kendall, Kerr and Travis Counties. We talked about the state of Texas agriculture and issues affecting farmers and ranchers including burdensome regulations from the EPA. I told them the work the House Science, Space and Technology Committee and Judiciary Committee are doing to rein in and roll back the costly and often arbitrary regulations that threaten their livelihoods.

Yesterday I met with health care providers that serve Real, Bexar, Hays and Travis Counties at Community Health Centers. I have and will continue to support these valuable facilities that provide  care to medically under-served populations.

I applaud the work Lt. Col. Tom Holubik and team are doing at HONOR Veterans Now out of Fredericksburg to honor veterans across the state. They provide young veterans who are struggling financially with life-sustaining, nutritious meals.
It was a joy to visit with Principal Crittenden and the students, faculty and staff at Ingram Independent School District's Tom Moore H.S. on Friday.
On live with The Daily Signal-

I have seen your questions and comments about last week's vote to disapprove of the FCC's regulations on data collection. Here's an article that explains why Congress's rejection of proposed FCC data rules will not affect your privacy.  https://www.forbes.com/sites/larrydownes/2017/03/30/why-congresss-rejection-of-proposed-fcc-data-rules-will-not-affect-your-privacy-in-the-slightest/#1370e54b8b14

Regarding a story many in the media are refusing to cover, or are saying is no big deal, yesterday I spoke on the House floor about how Susan Rice, a former national security advisor under President Obama, ordered the names of Trump associates who were under surveillance be revealed rather than kept confidential, as would normally be the case with any American citizen.   This exposing and disseminating personal information may well have been a criminal act. A serious question is, “Who authorized the surveillance in the first place?”
Today I spoke on the House floor about the impact of environmental regulations -
Justice Gorsuch will be an excellent addition to the Supreme Court since he believes the Constitution should be interpreted as written.

Yesterday, I toured GE Aviation's Digital Collaboration Center in Austin. At the Center, which opened this past fall, customers collaborate with GE Aviation engineers to solve flight operation problems using sensors, big data and analytics.
Congratulations to Texas Army ROTC!  https://news.utexas.edu/2017/04/11/ut-austin-army-rotc-no-1-in-the-nation

I toured the future site of EPIcenter (Energy, Partnerships, Innovation), which will be located in the former Mission Road Power Plant in San Antonio.  CEO Kimberly Britton shared how leaders from around the world will come to EPICenter to research, generate and promote new ideas surrounding new energy, and to engage citizens of all ages in discussions about energy transformation. EPIcenter leaders have billed the hub as San Antonio’s gift to the clean energy industry worldwide, as it is a local hub with global implications for the new energy economy.

This morning I met with Brigadier General Heather Pringle,  Commander of Joint Base San Antonio, for an update on their operations.  We discussed the challenges the base addresses as the San Antonio metropolitan area continues to grow and how JBSA works with city leaders, non-profits and other government agencies to find efficiencies and cost-savings through partnerships.

Today we remember one of our Founding Fathers and our third President, Thomas Jefferson. Jefferson's actions were crucial in shaping the look of the nation's capital and defining the powers of the Constitution and the nature of the emerging republic.

The need for aircraft mechanics continues to grow in San Antonio and around the country. The Bureau of Labor Statistics projects the country will need 3,500 more Aircraft and Avionics Equipment Mechanics and Technicians by 2022.   I visited the Hallmark College of Aeronautics where they train students to be able to fill that need. Hallmark simulates an aviation workplace environment so students learn to become mechanics and technicians in a real-world setting at their airport campus.
Happy Easter!

This week (April 15th to 23rd) is National Parks Week. Weekend admission is free, and there are many other activities throughout the week. Big Bend is beautiful if you can make the trip, but nearby are Lyndon B Johnson National Historical Park and the San Antonio Missions National Historical Park. Find your park at https://www.nps.gov/findapark/national-park-week.htm
Wish you owed less on #TaxDay? House Republicans' plan would increase Texans' after-tax income by $4,900 and create 140,000 jobs. Read more at https://waysandmeans.house.gov/taxreform/

Today I visited Elbit Systems in San Antonio to learn more about the work they’re doing in aeronautics research and development. Among many other services, Elbit manufactures unmanned aerial systems and satellites. Their technology is used to aid in a wide variety of missions from securing the border to observing earth from space.
I visited family-owned Toyota of Boerne to meet with dealership employees and tour the business. I appreciate you all sharing your thoughts on tax reform and policies that promote economic growth.

On this day in 1836, Texas won its final battle in the fight for independence. The battle of San Jacinto lasted only 18 minutes. Since 1891, the famous Battle of Flowers Parade has taken place in San Antonio as “the city’s way of paying homage to the Alamo dead and the heroes of San Jacinto."  http://www.expressnews.com/news/local/article/Heroes-of-the-Battle-of-San-Jacinto-still-11086620.php

Today is Tax Freedom Day, 113 days into 2017. Tax Freedom Day is a significant date for taxpayers and lawmakers because it represents how long Americans as a whole have to work in order to pay the nation’s tax burden. Americans will pay $3.5 trillion in federal taxes and $1.6 trillion in state and local taxes in 2017, for a total bill of more than $5.1 trillion. That's 31 percent of the nation’s income. To put that in perspective, America will spend more on taxes in 2017 than it will on food, clothing, and housing combined.  Learn more about Tax Freedom Day at https://taxfoundation.org/tax-freedom-day-2017/
Congratulations to the first Gary Job Corps in San Marcos graduates of 2017!  https://smcorridornews.com/gary-job-corps-graduation-2017/

Today I had the unique opportunity to reunite with one of the talented young Texans that I nominated to a U.S. service academy. Nominations are one of the most enjoyable roles I have. I met with Chase Wilke, who in 2006 as a New Braunfels Canyon H.S. student earned a nomination from me to attend the U.S. Air Force Academy. In 2017, he is now Captain Wilke, has completed multiple tours overseas in Afghanistan and Saudi Arabia, and will now be heading to Wharton Business School this fall.   After nominating Chase 11 years ago, it is rewarding to witness his personal and professional growth. I thank him for his patriotism and service to our country.

Allison Ashley, Texas' Teacher of the Year, visited me today in D.C. Ms. Ashley is in her 7th year of teaching bilingual education at Becker Elementary in Austin ISD. Learn more about her inspiration and love for learning in this video: https://vimeo.com/187399366

Did you know that this week is Small Business Week? Small Business Week is about the more than 75 MILLION Americans that work at small businesses. Meeting with small business owners and employees across Texas’ 21st district is one of my favorite parts of the job. These conversations help me learn two things 1) ideas on how we can simplify and lower the burden government has on their business and lives, so they can do more of 2) the positive role they play in their community. Small businesses create jobs and bring goods and services to their area that might not otherwise be there. This week we celebrate them. #SmallBusinessWeek
Setting aside a day for prayer and thanksgiving is a national tradition that first began with George Washington. Today we invite Americans of all faiths to pray for our nation. #NationalDayofPrayer

Today, May 9, we celebrate Teacher Appreciation Day, by acknowledging the essential role teachers play in ensuring every student receives a quality education. I have long considered teaching to be one of the most honorable professions in America. Thank you to all those committed to educating our nation’s students.

In the aftermath of the House’s passage of the American Health Care Act (AHCA), the rumor mill has been hard at work churning out irresponsible claims that simply aren’t true. Read here for a few fact checks squashing some of the most outrageous claims -   https://energycommerce.house.gov/news-center/news/fact-checks-dispel-hyperbolic-rhetoric-around-ahca

Texas' 21st district is home to over 60 thousand active duty servicemembers, veterans and - never to be forgotten about - their families. Today we thank military spouses for their invaluable contributions, support and sacrifice.

This week is National Police Week. We recognize and remember the law enforcement officers who lost their lives in the line of duty for the safety and protection of others. #NationalPeaceOfficersMemorialDay

This week the House Judiciary Committee is reviewing the Michael Davis, Jr. and Danny Oliver in Honor of State and Local Law Enforcement Act, commonly referred to as the Davis-Oliver Act.   The bill is named for two California law enforcement officers who were murdered by an illegal immigrant. Davis-Oliver is a necessary step to reinforce our immigration policies. President Obama unilaterally shut down immigration enforcement. This legislation ensures that the President of the United States cannot do that by granting states and localities specific congressional authorization to assist in the enforcement of federal immigration law. It also strengthens national security and protects American communities by improving visa security, facilitating the removal of dangerous criminal aliens, and barring terrorists from entering and remaining in the United States. Davis-Oliver has the support of the National Sheriffs Association and National Association of Former Border Patrol Officers.   I am proud to honor fallen officers Davis and Oliver by supporting this legislation that promotes the enforcement of our immigration laws.
Every child deserves to have a safe childhood. That’s why this week in Congress we voted on 8 House Judiciary Committee bills to protect our children and punish abusers.

From the Revolutionary War to the ongoing War on Terror, more than 1.3 million members of the American armed services have lost their lives in conflicts. The nature of war has changed, but the character of those who are willing to put their life on the line has not. As we take time during this holiday to honor our fallen heroes, we should also remember the sacrifices our troops and their families are making to ensure a safe future for our nation. They, and those who came before them, make the United States the land of the free and home of the brave.  I hope you’ll join me today in taking a moment to honor those who made the ultimate sacrifice.

It was my honor to present Lincoln Abbott of Fair Oaks Ranch the Congressional Award Gold Medal.   Congressional Award recipients represent the best in America – awardees must demonstrate voluntary public service, personal development, physical fitness and expedition. Lincoln volunteered with the Library of Congress to document the military experiences of veterans and helped at the VA Hospital. He’s also an award winning bagpiper and as part of his physical fitness goal he earned a higher degree Black Belt in Tae Kwon Do. Lincoln is now a certified coach, official and instructor in the martial art! For his exploration project, he traveled the Texas Independence Trail over four days and walked the battlefields where Texan settlers fought more than 175 years ago. Congratulations to Lincoln on his many achievements, including the The Congressional Award!

I am happy to see the Corps Work Plan prioritize the reimbursement of Bexar County funds. The Mission Reach habitat conservation and development project has generated community activity in a area that had previously been underutilized. This is a win for SARA, the county and the whole community of San Antonio.

On the anniversary of D-Day, we honor and remember those who bravely stormed the beaches of Normandy in the name of freedom. See how the San Antonio Express-News first shared the news of the Allied invasion 73 years ago here - http://www.expressnews.com/news/local/history-culture/article/June-7-1944-Allied-forces-launch-D-Day-11189687.php

Happy birthday to Vice President Mike Pence. Today Senator Ted Cruz, Rep. Brian Babin and I are joining him in traveling to our home state to visit NASA's Johnson Space Center in Houston to meet NASA's newest astronaut candidates. You can watch live starting at 1 p.m. C.T. at wh.gov/live #VPinTX

Today in Houston I had the opportunity to congratulate our newest NASA astronauts. Our American astronauts are the front line of U.S. exploration and discovery. This new class of astronauts is invaluable for the inspiration they provide to future generations of astronauts and the many studying STEM fields worldwide.

We have some talented high school students in Texas' 21st district! With their speeches and essays, these students earned a trip to our nation's capital sponsored by their local electric co-op. Our office had the great opportunity to meet them and give them a tour around the Capitol building complex. Thank you to Bandera Electric Cooperative, Central Texas Electric Cooperative, Medina Electric Cooperative, Inc. and Pedernales Electric Cooperative for sending these young leaders our way.   Electric Cooperative Youth Tour

The National VFW recognized VFW Post #12058 Kyle/Buda Commander Herman Fabela in their May/June magazine. Thank you for your service to our country and the Kyle and Buda area community, Commander Fabela.

Today I want to recognize Dixon Patillo. Mr. Patillo attended Fredericksburg Heritage School and in 2013 received a nomination from my office to attend the United States Military Academy (West Point). Second Lieutenant Patillo just graduated and his mother Sherri shared these photos of his special day with us. Congratulations Dixon!

More than 1 Million Texas students enroll in Career and Technical programs each year. These programs play a huge role in helping students secure competitive jobs.   That's why today I supported and the House passed the Strengthening Career and Technical Education for the 21st Century Act which provides essential education and skills to Americans so that they may build a promising career. This will help close the skills gap and equip Americans for a successful future. #CTE  Learn more about the legislation here: https://goo.gl/1WhCgR

For Alamo Heights High School in TX-21, “With rocketry, the sky’s the limit.” I wish the team the best of luck in their launch at White Sands next Wednesday!  http://www.expressnews.com/news/education/article/With-rocketry-the-sky-s-the-limit-11239464.php

This week dyslexia awareness advocates from across the U.S. are gathered in DC for #DyslexiaHillDays. Dyslexia affects an estimated 8.5 million school children and one in six Americans in some form.  Last year, President Obama signed into law my bill, the Research Excellence and Advancements for Dyslexia Act (READ Act) which supports important research to further our understanding of dyslexia, including better methods for early detection and teacher training. I look forward to continuing to work with advocates to ensure students with #dyslexia have opportunities for success. #sayDyslexia
I wish each of you a safe and happy Independence Day!

Today I had the opportunity to tour Trinity University's Center for Sciences and Innovation. University President Danny Anderson joined as Dr. Jonathan King, the chairman of the Trinity's biology department, and his summer research group students shared about the extensive research they're accomplishing and presented their developments so far. I look forward to learning more about their findings!

Today I voted in support of boosting resources for our military. As we know in Texas, a state where military culture runs deep, the men and women who keep us safe are our country’s most valuable asset. Congress has the responsibility to provide them the resources, care and pay raise they need, earned, and deserve. Read my full statement on the National Defense Authorization Act here - https://lamarsmith.house.gov/media-center/press-releases/rep-smith-votes-to-boost-resources-for-the-military

Recently, I had the great pleasure of touring Cox Manufacturing, a screw machine company in San Antonio. Cox employs more than 100 Texans and produces over a million parts every week. Visiting with plant employees and leadership reinforced how proud I am of all the companies in my district who make “Made in America” the world standard for quality and craftsmanship. #MadeinAmericaWeek   http://www.coxmanufacturing.com/congressman-smith-tour.htm

Did you know today is National Day of the American Cowboy?  They'll be celebrating today in Bandera, the Cowboy Capital of the world. As part of the event, Phillip F. Becker, Callie duPerier Apffel, and David Burell will be recognized as the newest members of the Texas Heroes Hall of Honor. Congratulations to these inductees and standout Texans!  http://www.bccourier.com/Archives/News_detail.php?contentId=25558  http://www.bccourier.com/Archives/News_detail.php?contentId=25562

Today in a House Homeland Security Committee hearing, I asked border security officials about the role that technology and physical structures play in enhancing U.S. Customs and Border Protection’s ability to secure the southwest border. Acting Deputy Chief of U.S. Border Patrol confirmed to me that physical barriers along the border help stop the flow of illegal immigrants. Physical barriers play a critical role in combination with more border personnel and technology to reducing illegal immigration.

Central and south Texas small business owners brought with them stories of how excessive regulations have impacted their companies. In Congress we're working to curtail those costly regulations, particularly those that disproportionately impact small businesses.

We owe much thanks to those who made sacrifices in the line of duty. Today is National Purple Heart Day, the day we commemorate the 1782 creation of the military decoration and honor. The Purple Heart is awarded to valiant soldiers who were injured or killed in combat.  Learn more about the history of the Purple Heart award at http://www.purpleheart.org/HistoryMedal2.aspx #Veterans #PurpleHeartDay

All, as Hurricane Harvey approaches, please make sure you and your family are prepared. The San Antonio Express-News provides recommendations here and you can also download the FEMA Federal Emergency Management Agency app to get alerts from your local weather service, safety tips and reminders and other resources. Continue to monitor local radio or TV stations for updated emergency information, and follow the instructions of state, local, and tribal officials.  http://www.expressnews.com/news/local/article/How-should-you-prepare-for-Harvey-11955660.php  https://www.fema.gov/mobile-app

My thoughts and prayers are with all those that have been affected by the devastation brought by Hurricane Harvey. I’m grateful to the local first responders and those from across the state and country that have come to assist those in need. The Federal Emergency Management Agency (FEMA) has over 8,300 employees helping in Texas now. If you or someone you know is in need assistance, please visit http://www.disasterassistance.gov.   Are you interested in helping Hurricane Harvey victims? Read here - http://www.chron.com/news/houston-weather/hurricaneharvey/article/Hurricane-Harvey-How-to-help-victims-of-the-12003372.php

Goodwill San Antonio is partnering with the American Red Cross to provide assistance to those affected by Hurricane Harvey.   Today I learned about their efforts – this past Saturday, the Goodwill San Antonio logistics team coordinated the delivery of our clothing items to over 800 evacuees housed in San Antonio. Since then they’ve coordinated with the Red Cross to make sure new evacuees have what they need to be more comfortable in this stressful time. Goodwill San Antonio President Kevin Bergner requests that those who want to help with the relief effort please visit redcross.org/donate.

Today I visited the San Antonio and Bexar County Emergency Operations Center and the Hurricane Harvey First Responder Deployment Center set up at the AT&T Center. Area leaders like Fire Chief Larry Treviño, SAPD Captain Patrick Murnin, and Ernest Gonzalez, Head of Operations at the First Responder Center and their teams have been working around the clock since last Thursday.    First they were working to make sure San Antonio was prepared for the storm, and then when Harvey took a different path, they began efforts to dispatch teams to the gulf coast and southeast Texas and execute plans for providing for evacuees in south and central Texas. While Hurricane Harvey has posed a challenge, Bexar County, the City of San Antonio, and organizations like Goodwill and the Red Cross are meeting that challenge head on, eagerly and competently.

President Obama, a former Constitutional law professor, said many times that DACA was unconstitutional. By ending the unconstitutional DACA program, President Trump has overturned the last of the Obama Administration’s amnesty agenda and returned to the rule of law.

Today with House Judiciary Committee Chairman Congressman Bob Goodlatte and Congressman Ken Calvert, I introduced the Legal Workforce Act (H.R. 3711) to protect jobs for Americans and legal workers by requiring U.S. employers to check the work eligibility of all future hires through the E-Verify system.   E-Verify quickly confirms 99.8% of work-eligible employees and takes less than two minutes to use. In this short video, I explain how to use the E-Verify system.  You can learn more abotu the Legal Workforce Act at https://judiciary.house.gov/wp-content/uploads/2017/09/Legal-Workforce-Act.pdf

Sixteen years ago, I witnessed one of the attacks on our homeland. Flight 77, which had departed Dulles International Airport and was bound for Los Angeles, changed course and crashed into the western side of the Pentagon. I was driving to work on a road that went by the Pentagon when I heard a noise to my right and then immediately saw black smoke rising from the building. I’d learned of the two attacks in New York, but now terrorists had hit our nation’s capital.   We all have memories of where we were that day when we heard the news. I have not forgotten that moment and the rest of the attacks that day that took the lives of so many Americans. Today as we honor those who died on September 11 and stand with their families, we continue working to ensure that this never happens again.   The attacks may have shattered our sense of safety, but they also have strengthened our resolve, national pride and preparedness. May we harness that strength as our country faces crises in the form of natural disasters and foreign threats.
One of the best articles on media bias I've ever read -

I am pleased to announce that my office is participating in the 2017 Congressional App Challenge. The Congressional App Challenge is a competition aimed at encouraging U.S. high school students to learn how to code by creating their own applications. The Challenge is intended to highlight the value of computer science and STEM education (Science, Technology, Engineering and Math).   Please share with students, parents, teachers, and administrators. The submission period goes through Nov. 1, 2017. Please note that this competition is open to all students who meet the eligibility requirements, regardless of coding experience. We strongly encourage students of all skill levels to participate, to learn how to create their own apps. The House of Representatives knows how crucial these skills are and wants to encourage students to engage in these fields. By encouraging and recognizing our nation’s young programming talent, Congress hopes to shine a light on the growing importance of these skills. To learn more about the Challenge or to submit an app, go to www.CongressionalAppChallenge.us.  #HouseofCode

This week I introduced the Immigration in the National Interest Act. I spoke on the House floor about the reforms this bill makes, and how similar legislation was recommended by the Jordan Commission, chaired by the Texas Democrat, former member Barbara Jordan; was liked by President Clinton; and was endorsed by many in the national media. How time changes.

This week I met with emerging young leaders in San Antonio who are involved in local government, business and the non-profit sector. These talented individuals are taking on challenges ranging from growing south Texas’s tech community to combating the opioid epidemic.

Apptronik is an Austin-based company that focuses on human-centered robot design and cutting edge components. Today I toured their lab and learned about their work developing robots that will make our lives safer, easier and more productive.

Today the House Committee on Science, Space, and Technology held a hearing on electric grid resiliency. We examined electric resiliency from both physical and cyber threats, and studied the effectiveness of private and government coordination on resiliency across the electricity delivery sectors to ensure that the electric grid can deliver power to American homes, businesses, and essential services.  You can watch my opening statement here, and please also take a moment to read my op-ed in the Houston Chronicle, "Electric grid resiliency - the update America needs," coauthored with Congressman Randy Weber and Rep. Brian Babin: http://www.houstonchronicle.com/opinion/outlook/article/Smith-Weber-Babin-Electric-grid-resiliency-12247592.php

Today I voted to protect the sanctity of life with my support for the Pain-Capable Unborn Child Protection Act (H.R. 36), which restricts abortions 20 weeks or more after fertilization. The legislation passed in the House 237-189. Read more about the bill and my full statement at https://goo.gl/UpdULo.

I wrote in The Hill about why we need to expand #EVerify and apply it to all employers. Simply put, E-Verify saves jobs for American workers. My 1996 bill created the pilot for the system which allows employers to check the work eligibility of all future hires. Read the full piece here -   http://thehill.com/blogs/congress-blog/homeland-security/353648-e-verify-saves-job-for-american-workers

Last week I visited Boerne High School and talked with student council members Hunter Beaton, David Noble, Carson Harris, Grace Hendry, Tanner Hoke, BHS Principal Natalie Garber and BHS Student Council Sponsor Elizabeth Wolff. While I was there, Hunter Beaton explained his Day 1 Bag project to me. When Beaton was brainstorming on his Eagle Scout project over a year ago, his thoughts went back to how when his now-adopted siblings first entered his home, they had all of their belongings in black trash bags. Beaton decided he wanted to give children in the foster system a high quality bag to hold their belongings, and thus Day 1 Bags was created.   Hunter is making a big difference in the lives of kids and for his efforts has been named a Texas Board of Education Student Hero, recognized by the Texas VFW as Scout of the Year, and received several other awards. Read more about Hunter and Day 1 Bags at Sustainability - Day 1 Bags and https://www.hillcountryweekly.com/single-post/2017/08/11/Boerne-Teen%E2%80%99s-Eagle-Scout-Project-Improving-the-Lives-of-Foster-Kids

Tonight the House Judiciary Committee approved by a vote of 20-10 a bill I authored and introduced - the Legal Workforce Act (H.R. 3711). The legislation preserves jobs for U.S. citizens and legal workers by requiring U.S. employers to check the work eligibility of all future hires through the E-Verify system.  The American people like E-Verify. A September 2017 Washington Post-ABC News poll shows that 82% of voters favor requiring business owners to check the immigration status of employees they hire. And the system is simple - in this video I show how easy it is to use: https://youtu.be/Y7d3txF5ZzI

Today the House passed a budget resolution which was a critical benchmark to fulfill our promise of comprehensive tax reform for the American people. I spoke on the House floor today about the need to reduce the tax burden on hard-working Americans. This includes reforms like enhancing the Child Tax Credit, which will help families keep more of their paycheck to use on childcare or parental leave, school supplies, college savings and other expenses associated with raising a child.
Just one more day! ⏳ Students, submit your apps to The Congressional App Challenge at http://www.congressionalappchallenge.us/ by Nov. 1 @ 12noon ET (11 a.m. Central Time)! #Congress4CS

There will also be several events taking place in the 21st district area where veterans can learn more about SBA resources and a "Hiring Red White & You" job fair - more info at https://www.sba.gov/veterans-small-business-week-events #MyVetBiz

The House tax plan makes the tax code simpler, flatter and fairer for Americans and makes it more competitive for American businesses. With an increase in the Child Tax Credit, American families will have more of their hard-earned money to spend on the costs associated with raising a child.  Learn more about the plan to make your taxes simpler and more fair at https://fairandsimple.gop/

Friends, I am announcing today that I will not be seeking re-election next year. Representing the 21st District and its more than 700,000 residents is an honor almost beyond description. Serving you all is an immense privilege and with over a year remaining in my term, there is still much to do. Read more here -

I’m deeply saddened by the news coming out of Sutherland Springs. We’re continuing to learn updates on the tragic shooting in which 26 innocent lives were taken and more injured. Thank you to all those in South Texas – law enforcement, first responders, medical staff and others – who have come together to help victims and their loved ones.

On Veterans Day, we honor all our veterans. These men and women put their lives on the line to defend our nation and our freedoms. The United States is stronger and safer today because of those willing to make the ultimate sacrifice.  While we will never be able to truly repay our veterans, we must work to ensure veterans receive proper care and support. Already this year, the House has passed over 25 bills aimed at helping our former service members, and their families. This includes the Harry W. Colmery Veterans Assistance Act, a landmark bill that expands opportunities for veterans by removing the 15-year time limit on the use of GI bill benefits. Additionally, I have supported multiple measures that will increase accountability at the VA, provide jobs for servicemen and servicewomen, and ensure that all veterans receive the benefits and care they deserve.  Assisting our veterans is a priority every day, not just today. The 21st Congressional District is home to over 60,000 veterans, current members of the military and their families. If my office can ever be of assistance with questions or concerns regarding veterans' benefits, please contact my San Antonio, Austin or Kerrville District Offices.

Today I voted in support of the 2018 National Defense Authorization Act (NDAA). The bipartisan bill passed 356-70 and will now go to the President's desk to be signed into law.   With this bill we are providing the means to rebuild and maintain our military. The included 2.4 percent pay raise in the bill is the highest in eight years. The legislation also increases the number of troops, provides greater training opportunities, and prioritizes the restoration and modernization of our military facilities.

Today we kept our promise to the American people by passing pro-family, pro-growth tax reform for working Americans. The Tax Cuts and Jobs Act creates jobs, reduces taxes and gives bigger paychecks to families.  This bill raises incomes for families in Texas by an average of $2,558. This bill increases the child tax credit from $1000 to $1600 to provide more support for Texans taking care of their children. Over 45,000 taxpayers in the 21st district will benefit from the child credit increase.  The legislation also simplifies the tax code – nine out of ten Americans will be able to file their taxes on a form the size of a post card.  The tax rates for small and family-owned businesses and corporations are reduced. This encourages companies to bring their foreign profits and jobs back to the U.S. for American workers.

Happy Thanksgiving! I’m thankful for my family, friends and colleagues and the privilege of representing the 21st Congressional District. I hope you have a blessed day with your loved ones and friends and can join me in taking a moment to express gratitude to servicemembers whose sacrifices for us mean they are apart from their families today.

Learn more about Kaci and other UT students’ work at the RENEU Robotics Laboratory at https://reneu.robotics.utexas.edu/.
